name: Keghan Myers
comment info:
From the four dot plots given, you can see that the US has the highest cell phone service rates, as well as the highest health expenditures out of all the countries shown. name: Patric Dailey

replies.name: J
replies.comment info: @Patric Dailey I actually know a little about the health expenditures bit, and that's because the majority of drug testing/medical innovation is funded by the government! Also, we're a world leader in medical innovation which is super expensive, but our healthcare system as it stands makes it well worth the cost due to insane price gouging- which has led to medical debt becoming the leading cause of bankruptcies in America (66.5%). name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s graphs show the four measures of economic and personal well-being of its citizens.  There are 42 countries on some or all of these graph.

The graphs appeared online in the article “The U.S. Is Lagging Behind Many Rich Countries These Charts Show Why. ” (URL in the release.)  By viewing the graphs online, you can see the name of the country for each point on the graphs.

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and “What impact does this topic have on you?”  Better insights result from your discussing with your classmates what you all notice and wonder.  After you’ve learned from others, then respond online.  

Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas in these graphs. 

By Friday morning, we’ll reveal the article that included these graphs and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.
 
Note that you can get a link to your response to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”  

Keep noticing and wondering.  Stay tuned for the next release on Friday, Dec. 11 with moderation on Wednesday, Dec. 16.  The last graph of 2020 is about your choice for instant mastery!

replies.name: R
replies.comment info: @Skye MacLeod I think part of the high cell cost has to do with the system of privatized cell networks that we have in America. It used to be that the American Telegraph and Telephone Company had a monopoly on long-distance telephone services. After the original AT&T was broken up, it was split into multiple regional telephone companies called “baby bells,” which were supposed to foster competition. However, due to lack of updating antitrust laws, these companies started merging again. Now we have four big players in the cell service industry, each of which have regional monopolies. These companies don’t have to provide cell services for customers of other cell companies on cell towers they build. So while people in other countries have relatively cheap cell service anywhere in the country, Americans have generally worse and more costly cell service. I think it’s time to break up the phone companies again.
